title: Little Britain’s return could be more divisive than Brexit itself
text:
Little Britain have their work cut out for them (Picture: BBC)

There was a time when David Walliams and Matt Lucas were the kind of comedy duo that were set to rival Ant and Dec as the UK’s fave pairing.

The jewel in the BBC’s comedy schedule crown at the turn of the millennium, there was literally nowhere you could go without hearing a Little Britain catchphrase being yelled.

But let’s be real here, the world has grown up in the 13 years since the show last appeared on air, and it has aged really, really, badly.

So it should hardly come as a surprise that Little Britain’s Brexit special, albeit in a one-off radio special, would be more divisive than Brexit itself.

Scrap that, the return of Little Brexit was met with an almost overwhelming united cry of ‘we don’t want this’. But hey, at least everyone would’ve been united on something on 31 October, before Boris Johnson moved the deadline again.

Advertisement

Advertisement

So, David and Matt, you have a hell of a lot of making up to do if there’s even a thought that this show could get legs again.

We’ve come too far as a country to step back into the world of ‘I’m a Lady’ (Picture: BBC)

Previously speaking about any potential reunion to the Big Issue, Matt admitted he was aware and embarrassed of the show’s controversial characters.

‘If I could go back and do Little Britain again, I wouldn’t make those jokes about transvestites,’ he told the mag. ‘I wouldn’t play black characters.

‘Basically, I wouldn’t make that show now. It would upset people. We made a more cruel kind of comedy than I’d do now.’

‘Society has moved on a lot since then and my own views have evolved,’ he added. ‘There was no bad intent there – the only thing you could accuse us of was greed.’

With that in mind, it’s not the greatest start in the world that all the show’s tired clichés seem ready to be wheeled out for listeners once again – the only gay in the village Dafydd, gobby working class benefit scrounger Vicky Pollard, Fat Fighters’ Marjorie Dawes, and, you guessed it, Emily ‘I’m A Lady’ Howard.

For someone who’s only just said that character has died a death, especially in the 13 years of societal growth the UK has been through since it last aired on TV, what on earth possessed them to bring, of all people, Emily back.

Vicky Pollard will be revisited in the radio special (Picture: BBC)

At least on the radio the pair don’t have to run the risk of falling into old habits and wearing fat-suits and blackface in a bid to get a laugh (both of which are present and correct in Walliams’ Desiree in Little Britain.) Though you have to kind of wonder what it is they’re going to be talking about.

Advertisement

Advertisement

With a character like council estate Vicky around, and the stereotypical trope she often falls into, it wouldn’t be surprising to hear some pro-Brexit, anti-immigrant nonsense she doesn’t understand coming out of her mouth when she’s not watching Love Island, we assume.

Why do you think Britain should leave the EU? Yeah but, no but, yeah but, no but…

(While that sounds like I’m the one being offensive, this was a character that was displayed wheeling around six kids in an extended trolley, before trading one in for a Westlife CD and exchanging sexual favours for electronic equipment.)

And what is ‘rubbish transvestite’ Emily (their words not mine) without the screeches of ‘I’m a Lady’ defining every sentence? With the sexual revolution upon us, is Dafydd going to remain the Only Gay In The Village™? Or, god forbid, decide that seeing as everyone else was gay, he was going to be sexually liberated in some other way, and preach that to the masses.

We’re sure Dafydd will have some thoughts on Brexit (Picture: BBC)

Please, please don’t be these people you two. You need to be better than what is currently running through mine and hundreds of other peoples’ heads right now.

By all means, share both sides of the Leave/Remain coin, and do it well. Don’t resort to cheap, mocking that by your own words was ‘cruel’ even 13 years ago.

In the years that have passed both Lucas and Walliams have become household names in their own right. Not only that, family friendly names.

Advertisement

This is despite their follow-up show, Come Fly With Me, featuring them in blackface, brownface yellowface. They’ve somehow managed to have that smited from their record in favour of children’s books and Britain’s Got Talent.

More: Brexit Boris Johnson welcomes back 10 MPs who rebelled against him EU citizens and 16-year-olds will not be allowed to vote in December election How to register to vote as Boris Johnson attempts to secure General Election

But the very pinnacle of the show and what it’s based on is terrifying, and leaves so much room for error you can’t help but feel that something is about to go seriously wrong.

You guys have a short period of time to autocorrect years of offensive sketches that have marked British culture.

I wish you the best, but can’t help but think this is a bit of a thankless venture.

Little Brexit airs Thursday at 6.30pm on BBC Radio 4.
